head.title: When Knowledge Runs Into Stage Fright

hedline.hl1: When Knowledge Runs Into Stage Fright

abstract.p: Gerelyn Hollingsworth letter on May 31 article holds National Geography Bee should give written tests instead of requiring contestants to perform on stage; drawing

block.p: Re ''Girls a Distant 2nd in Geography Gap Among U.S. Pupils'' (front page, May 31):
The National Geography Bee tests not only knowledge of geography but also the ability to call that knowledge to mind on stage in front of hundreds of people.
Re ''Girls a Distant 2nd in Geography Gap Among U.S. Pupils'' (front page, May 31):
The National Geography Bee tests not only knowledge of geography but also the ability to call that knowledge to mind on stage in front of hundreds of people.
The school bees and the state bees that children must win to make it to the finals in Washington require public performance, and many children are eliminated because of stage fright.
Geographers do not work on stages in front of audiences. They work in private in their offices with their computers and their atlases and maps and other reference material.
The National Geography Bee should give written tests instead of requiring the contestants to perform on stage.
